reviews.text: This is quintessentially the British seaside. Fantastic beach, excellent Seaview fish restaurant traditional pier, funicular railway, model railway and beautiful park alongside the river. A terrific place to bring the children. With the right weather a great day out is guaranteed.
Fabulous place to visit. Victorian splendour on seafront and great ride on Funicular down cliff.

Sadly the imposing station building is no longer used for the purpose for which it was built, though at least it remains largely intact.  The width of the two platforms still extant hint at the popularity of the town as a recreational destination in days of yore and as it is now the station is still a pleasant enough place to wait for a train on a warm summer day. Services are fairly frequent, though from the quality of the ride the passenger might be forgiven for thinking the trains should really be in a museum. However, many places of equal if not bigger size lost their link to the rail network many years ago so it is best to be thankful for small mercies and appreciate the colourful, if modest floral display when blooms are in abundance.

If you like Victorian, this place is for you (and me). The town is well presented and pretty with a good selection of shops, as well as the famous cliff tram lift down to the pier and seafront, where excellent fish and chips can be enjoyed. The valley gardens and woods provide lovely walks for all, dogs especially, with a tea room which is dog friendly. Saltburn also has the farmers market every 2nd Saturday in the month providing good local produce, it's well worth a visit.

Nice old Victorian train station set in a lovely seaside town.

Although originally a small settlement and the haunt of smugglers, the Stockton & Darlington Railway Company reached Saltburn in 1861. Subsequently Saltburn was formally planned as a new town in the late 19th Century by the Saltburn Improvement Company.
